topic.title: HP Helion OpenStack Carrier Grade 2.1: Restart MySQL and RabbitMQ

body.p: A default deployment of HP Helion OpenStack Carrier Grade includes a MySQL database instance and RabbitMQ instance on each controller, configured as a MySQL cluster.

In HP Helion OpenStack Carrier Grade 2.1, the controllers are virtual machines on a single server. In the event that server goes down, you will need to manually restart the MySQL servers after the server is restarted. You might also need to restart RabbitMQ.

section.title: Restarting MySQL
section.p:
If the server hosting the controller VMs goes down, the MySQL server on each controller will need to be manually restarted. HP Helion OpenStack Carrier Grade includes an Ansible playbook that will:
shut down all MySQL servers
perform a mysql stop command to clear potential errors
query the status of the MySQL cluster to determine the last MySQL server to fail
bootstrap that MySQL server
restart the other MySQL servers

ol.li:
Log into the lifecycle manager. ssh <HLM_VM_IP>
where: HLM_VM_IP is the CLM IP of the lifecycle manager. Locate the IP address for the lifecycle manager in the ~/infra-ansible-playbooks/group_vars/all file under hlm_clmstaticip field.
Stop then start the service:hlm stop -c <cloud name> -t FND-MDB hlm start -c <cloud name> -t FND-MDB
Log into the controller ssh cghelion@<IP of Controller>

Execute the following command to determine the status of the MySQL cluster:"sudo mysql keystone -e \"show status where Variable_name in ('wsrep_cluster_size','wsrep_cluster_status','wsrep_incoming_addresses');"\"This command should return a cluster status where all VMs are listed.

section.title: Restarting RabbitMQ
section.p: If the server hosting the controller VMs goes down, the RabbitMQ message broker service might need to be manually restarted.

ol.li:
Log into the lifecycle manager. ssh <HLM_VM_IP>
where: HLM_VM_IP is the CLM IP of the lifecycle manager. Locate the IP address for the lifecycle manager in the ~/infra-ansible-playbooks/group_vars/all file under hlm_clmstaticip field.
Stop then start the service:hlm stop -c <cloud name> -t FND-RMQ hlm start -c <cloud name> -t FND-RMQ
Log into the controller ssh cghelion@<IP of Controller>
Execute the following command to determine the status of the RabbitMQ cluster:"sudo rabbitmqctl cluster_status"
Execute the following command to determine the status of the RabbitMQ cluster:"sudo rabbitmqctl cluster_status"This command should return a cluster status where all VMs are listed.
